title: Pahuri
text:
Pahuri is a village in <a href="Sareni%2C%20Uttar%20Pradesh">Sareni</a> block of <a href="Rae%20Bareli%20district">Rae Bareli district</a>, <a href="Uttar%20Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>, <a href="India">India</a>. It is located 11 km from <a href="Lalganj%2C%20Uttar%20Pradesh">Lalganj</a>, the <a href="tehsil">tehsil</a> headquarters. As of 2011, it has a population of 1,122 people, in 196 households. It hosts both a regular market and a weekly <a href="haat">haat</a>. It belongs to the <a href="nyaya%20panchayat">nyaya panchayat</a> of <a href="Bhoremau">Bhoremau</a>.
The <a href="1951%20Census%20of%20India">1951 census</a> recorded Pahuri as comprising 21 hamlets, with a total population of 2,032 people (1,026 male and 1,006 female), in 350 households and 311 physical houses. The area of the village was given as 1,398 <a href="acre">acre</a>s. 138 residents were literate, 133 male and 5 female. The village was listed as belonging to the <a href="pargana">pargana</a> of <a href="Sareni%2C%20Uttar%20Pradesh">Sareni</a> and the <a href="thana">thana</a> of Sareni.
The <a href="1961%20Census%20of%20India">1961 census</a> recorded Pahuri as comprising 17 hamlets, with a total population of 2,273 people (1,184 male and 1,089 female), in 366 households and 353 physical houses. The area of the village was given as 1,398 <a href="acre">acre</a>s and it had a post office at that point. It was then part of Lalganj block.
The <a href="1981%20Census%20of%20India">1981 census</a> recorded Pahuri as having a population of 2,927 people, in 469 households, and having an area of 565.76 <a href="hectare">hectare</a>s. The main staple foods were given as wheat and rice.
The <a href="1991%20Census%20of%20India">1991 census</a> recorded Pahuri as having a total population of 3,444 people (1,748 male and 1,696 female), in 568 households and 567 physical houses. The area of the village was listed as 586 hectares. Members of the 0-6 age group numbered 563, or 16% of the total; this group was 54% male (303) and 46% female (260). Members of <a href="scheduled%20castes">scheduled castes</a> made up 22% of the village's population, while no members of <a href="scheduled%20tribes">scheduled tribes</a> were recorded. The <a href="literacy%20rate">literacy rate</a> of the village was 39% (904 men and 433 women). 1,071 people were classified as main workers (766 men and 305 women), while 32 people were classified as marginal workers (11 men and 21 women); the remaining 2,341 residents were non-workers. The breakdown of main workers by employment category was as follows: 581 cultivators (i.e. people who owned or leased their own land); 332 agricultural labourers (i.e. people who worked someone else's land in return for payment); 11 workers in livestock, forestry, fishing, hunting, plantations, orchards, etc.; 0 in mining and quarrying; 20 household industry workers; 40 workers employed in other <a href="manufacturing">manufacturing</a>, processing, service, and repair roles; 0 <a href="construction%20worker">construction worker</a>s; 20 employed in trade and commerce; 6 employed in transport, storage, and communications; and 61 in other services.
